results.title: We discovered North Norway
results.brief_description: A train trip in the land of the midnight sun, through more than 500 tunnels. Per Host shows the grandeur of Northern Norway, which until recently very few Norwegians had ever seen. It is a geographical anomaly that here, north of the arctic circle, one can sun-bathe and swim in the fjords amid the towering peaks and plunging ravines.

results.title: Way to a New World
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The old and the new in Papua New Guinea. The traditional way of life in the villages; trade with other villages, the belief in magic, raising garden crops, management of village affairs by the old men in secret, feasts and sing-sings, the initiation of the young men. The new ways; opportunities for education, improved health and child welfare, the introduction of cash crops and native cooperation associations, the formation of elected Local Government Councils.

results.title: The Land my mother = Walya ngamardiki
results.creator_credit: India Bharti, David Roberts, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Inspired by Silas Roberts, a tribal elder of the Allawa clan who wrote to the 1976 Australian Government inquiry on uranium mining, this film gives an insight into the Aborigines’ attitude towards uranium mining. They tell of the myths and legends associated with the land and their sacred places, and why they object to the mining being carried out. Commentary by Bob Maza.

results.title: The Venomous Australians
results.brief_description: A discussion of the various venomous creatures in Australia. Looks at snakes, spiders, and other insects and marine animals.

results.title: Transport today
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Education Media Australia
results.brief_description: This film provides a brief survey of modern transport. The film has been produced without commentary, only natural effects, and has been designed as an introduction to the study of transport. The film does not deal with any one aspect in detail but shows a range of examples which makes a good starting point for inquiry.

results.title: 'Where dead men lie': spotlight the director
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Chris McGill, Richard Mason and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the production of “Where dead men lie”, highlighting the role of the director, Keith Gow. This film shows his involvement in screen testing, location shooting, editing and mixing. Suitable for Years 7-12.

results.title: Stirring the pool
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, Gil Brealey, Peter Weir, Commonwealth Public Service Board and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
A new typist is asked to do a job for the manager instead of the senior typist, who is not present. Afterwards the senior typist voices her resentment, causing the new girl to feel unhappy. Another typist informs the new typist that the attitude of the senior typist is not new and has caused many resignations. What is the answer to internal warfare in the typing pool? Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: School's in, Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Examines the present school system in the Soviet Union. Demonstrates the style of Soviet teaching which is fairly rigid and formal, with the emphasis on teacher dominated instruction and passive pupils, responding only when instructed to do so. A more flexible teaching style was introduced some years ago but was later abandoned. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Queensland Centenary Story, 1859-1959
results.creator_credit: Judy Campbell, Dulcie Holland, Eric Thompson, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A brief account of the first hundred years of Queensland’s history, touching on its social life, its connection with two world wars, its industries and its agricultural and pastoral pursuits. Many sequences of historical intrest - in particular the visit of the Prince of Wales in 1921 and the Trans-Pacific flight by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith.
